project_metadata.paper_title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
project_metadata.research_context: This study analyses genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning approximately 5400-2400 BC to understand the genetic interactions between late Copper Age farming societies and emerging pastoralist groups from the Eurasian steppes.

evidence.description: Genome-wide data successfully generated from 135 out of 216 attempted ancient individuals from eight distinct sites
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites

evidence.description: Samples enriched for 1.24 million SNPs with coverage ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs and average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×
evidence.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

evidence.description: Chronological distribution: Neolithic (n=1), Copper Age (n=95), Eneolithic (n=18), Early Bronze Age (n=21)
evidence.verbatim_quote: ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)

evidence.description: 113 new radiocarbon dates obtained for ancient individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

evidence.description: PCA constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations onto which ancient data were projected
evidence.verbatim_quote: we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

evidence.description: Earliest individual PIE039 from Pietrele falls within expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space
evidence.verbatim_quote: The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space

evidence.description: Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N most symmetrically related to PIE039 with |Z| ≤ 1 for all HG comparisons
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N to be most symmetrically related to PIE039 with respect to all HG comparisons (|Z| ≤ 1)

evidence.description: SEE CA individuals from Yunatsite, Varna, Pietrele and Petko Karavelovo form a tight cluster overlapping with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE in PCA
evidence.verbatim_quote: the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE

evidence.description: All SEE CA groups slightly shifted towards EHG/WHG cline compared to most published Neolithic individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: all SEE CA groups are slightly shifted towards the EHG/WHG cline in both PC1 and PC2 compared to most published Neolithic individuals

evidence.description: Distal qpAdm modelling confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry for SEE CA
evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry

evidence.description: Proximal qpAdm modelling shows all SEE CA groups can be modelled as single-source from locally preceding Neolithic groups
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model

evidence.description: Outlier PIE060 shows excess HG ancestry confirmed by f4 statistics |Z| ≥ 3
evidence.verbatim_quote: The outlier individual PIE060 is shifted further towards the WHG/EHG cluster in PCA, suggesting an excess of this type of ancestry, which could be confirmed by f4 statistics of the form f4(SEE N, PIE060; HGs, Mbuti) ((|Z| ≥ 3)

evidence.description: PIE060 ancestry modelling: approximately 65% SEE N and 35% Iron Gates HG or KO1
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies

evidence.description: DATES admixture estimate for PIE060: 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), corresponding to approximately 81-832 years before mean 14C date
evidence.verbatim_quote: we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), which corresponds to around 81–832 years before the mean 14C date of PIE060

evidence.description: Y-chromosomal diversity at Pietrele: 7 different main lineages among 29 males (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a, R1b-V88)
evidence.verbatim_quote: With seven different main lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a and R1b-V88)

evidence.description: Y-chromosomal diversity at Varna: 6 different lineages among 15 males (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1, R1b-V88)
evidence.verbatim_quote: six among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1 and R1b-V88)

evidence.description: Y-chromosomal diversity at Yunatsite: 4 different lineages among 6 males (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a)
evidence.verbatim_quote: four among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a)

evidence.description: READ analysis detected only 3 first-degree and 2 second-degree relationships total across SEE CA sites
evidence.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

evidence.description: IBD analysis found no evidence for between-site links up to fourth-fifth degree; only two pairs shared ≥2 blocks >20cM (fifth-seventh degree)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

evidence.description: hapROH analysis indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes
evidence.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes

evidence.description: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals dated approximately 4500-3500 BC form a genetic cline in PCA between Neolithic/SEE CA and Eneolithic steppe individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals

evidence.description: No correlation found between Ukraine Eneolithic individuals' PC2 positions and their 14C dates (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)
evidence.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

evidence.description: Kartal individuals highly heterogeneous: 5 individuals (Kartal A) form cline between Steppe Eneolithic/Maykop and Early Neolithic; 3 individuals (Kartal B) fall closer to Neolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous, with five individuals (Kartal A) forming a cline between 'Steppe Eneolithic'/'Steppe Maykop' individuals and Early Neolithic groups, while three other individuals (Kartal B) fall closer to the latter

evidence.description: Majaky (5 individuals) and Usatove (4 individuals) genetically more homogeneous, falling in middle of 'Kartal cline'
evidence.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous and fall together with the four individuals from the late Eneolithic Usatove type-site (USV/UBK; Supplementary Table A) in the middle of the 'Kartal cline'

evidence.description: f4 statistics show Ukraine Eneolithic excess affinity to all HG groups compared to Turkey_N (|Z| ≥ 3)
evidence.verbatim_quote: compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

evidence.description: Conditioning on Steppe Eneolithic: Ukraine Eneolithic shows excess affinity to Turkey_N, symmetrical to CHG/WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic carries more EHG/WSHG
evidence.verbatim_quote: conditioning on Steppe Eneolithic, we observe excess affinity of Ukraine Eneolithic to Turkey_N, a symmetrical relatedness to CHG and WHG, while Steppe Eneolithic groups carry more EHG/WSHG ancestry

evidence.description: Distal qpAdm supports four-way admixture (Turkey_N, EHG, CHG, WHG) for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using distal qpAdm modelling we find support for a four-way admixture of Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV

evidence.description: KTL003, KTL006, KTL008 can be modelled with three sources (Turkey_N+EHG+CHG); KTL_B only with Turkey_N (~60%), CHG (~28%), WHG (~12%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: individuals KTL003, KTL006 and KTL008 can be modelled alternatively with three sources (Turkey_N+EHG+CHG) and KTL_B individuals only with Turkey_N (around 60%), CHG (around 28%) and WHG (around 12%) ancestry

evidence.description: All Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as two-way model of VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia + Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that all Ukraine Eneolithic individuals can be modelled as a two-way model of either VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia as farmer-related ancestry source and Steppe Eneolithic as a source of mixed EHG+CHG ancestry

evidence.description: KTL001 modelled as three-way mixture: Steppe Eneolithic (~32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (~46%), Ukraine N (~22%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source

evidence.description: MAJ and USV modelled as VAR_CA/Ukraine Trypillia (~50%), Steppe Eneolithic (~35%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (~15%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: MAJ and USV can be modelled as VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia (around 50%), Steppe Eneolithic (around 35%) and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 15%) as minor third component

evidence.description: KTL_B: VAR_CA (~73%), Steppe Eneolithic (~10%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: KTL_B results in the same model but with a higher VAR_CA component (around 73%) and a minor contribution of Steppe Eneolithic (around 10%) ancestry

evidence.description: Rotating model approach shows strong support for SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop contribution for most KTL individuals
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals (except KTL_B), which can be modelled as Steppe Eneolithic and VAR_CA

evidence.description: USV requires Maykop-associated ancestry; four-way mixture model P = 0.93
evidence.verbatim_quote: the competing model, with Maykop as an additional source and VAR_CA as an outgroup, results in a well-fit four-way mixture model for USV (P = 0.93)

evidence.description: IBD analysis shows fourth-sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites

evidence.description: ROH indicate elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV suggesting smaller effective population sizes
evidence.verbatim_quote: ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV, suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

evidence.description: Ukraine Eneolithic Y-chromosomes: G2a (Neolithic legacy), three males I2a1, KTL005 R1b/M343(×P297), MAJ009 R1b1/L754(×M269)
evidence.verbatim_quote: G2a is probably a Neolithic legacy, while three males carrying I2a1 could be attributed to the local Ukrainian Neolithic or HG groups in general. KTL005 and MAJ009 carry haplotypes R1b/M343(×P297) and R1b1/L754(×M269), respectively

evidence.description: No R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages observed in Ukraine Eneolithic males
evidence.verbatim_quote: we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

evidence.description: EBA individuals form two contrasting clusters in PCA: YUN/PIE078 resemble SEE CA; BOY_EBA/MAJ_EBA fall within 'steppe ancestry' cluster
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from YUN and individual PIE078, who date to the first half of the third millennium bc, resemble the SEE CA groups, whereas BOY_EBA and MAJ_EBA individuals fall within the 'steppe ancestry' cluster

evidence.description: Outliers BOY019 and YUN041 fall between the two EBA clusters in PCA
evidence.verbatim_quote: Two outlier individuals, BOY019 and YUN041, fall in the space between

evidence.description: YUN_EBA/PIE078 males carried Y-chromosome lineage I2a (HG legacy); BOY/MAJ_EBA males carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages
evidence.verbatim_quote: the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

evidence.description: f4 statistics confirm excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with |Z| ≤ 3
evidence.verbatim_quote: we tested for additional attraction towards HG-related groups in YUN_EBA and PIE078 compared to their CA predecessors by using f4(CA, EBA; HGs, Mbuti) and confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results (|Z| ≤ 3)

evidence.description: Only YUN041 has higher affinity to VAR_CA than other EBA groups when testing for farmer-related ancestry
evidence.verbatim_quote: only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

evidence.description: Distal qpAdm: PIE078/YUN_EBA modelled with Turkey_N, CHG, WHG; MAJ_EBA/BOY_EBA/BOY019/YUN041 require EHG as additional source
evidence.verbatim_quote: PIE078 and YUN_EBA can be modelled with Turkey_N, CHG and WHG, whereas MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA, BOY019 and YUN041 require EHG ancestry as an additional source

evidence.description: All EBA individuals show excess affinity to Turkey_N when compared to Steppe Eneolithic (except Yamnaya Caucasus)
evidence.verbatim_quote: With the exception of Yamnaya Caucasus, all EBA individuals show an excess affinity to Turkey_N when compared to Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.description: All f4 statistics non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) for Yamnaya comparisons except Ukraine_Ozera_EBA_Yamnaya outlier
evidence.verbatim_quote: all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

evidence.description: BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara modelled as three-way mixture: Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, Ukraine N
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N

evidence.description: BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA, Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as two-way: Steppe Eneolithic + KTL001
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic and KTL001

evidence.description: Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya: three-way model P = 0.07 (Steppe Eneolithic ~75%, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop ~14%, Globular Amphora ~11%); two-way P = 0.5 (Steppe Eneolithic ~65%, USV ~35%)
evidence.verbatim_quote: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source but also improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 65%) and USV (around 35%)

evidence.description: Yamnaya Caucasus modelled as two-way: ~76% Steppe Eneolithic, ~26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop
evidence.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop

evidence.description: Ozera outlier: two-way model P = 0.09 (40% Steppe Eneolithic + 60% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop)
evidence.verbatim_quote: This two-way mix (40% + 60%, respectively) also provides a well-fit model (P = 0.09) for the Ozera outlier individual

evidence.description: BOY019 modelled as ~63% USV + ~37% Steppe Eneolithic OR ~40% Ukraine Trypillia + ~60% Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individual BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.description: YUN041 modelled as ~50% local YUN_EBA + ~50% BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya source
evidence.verbatim_quote: individual YUN041 can be modelled as around 50% local YUN_EBA ancestry and 50% of either BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya-associated source

evidence.description: 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth processed in total
evidence.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total

evidence.description: Mitochondrial capture yielded average coverage of 64×
evidence.verbatim_quote: an average coverage of 64×

evidence.description: YMCA capture yielded mean coverage of 0.08× for Y chromosome
evidence.verbatim_quote: which resulted in a mean coverage of 0.08×

evidence.description: DNA damage patterns: 6-17% deamination for partial UDG treatment, 30-38% for non-UDG treatment
evidence.verbatim_quote: postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment)

evidence.description: ContamMix contamination estimates: 0.086% to -9.2% on mitochondrium
evidence.verbatim_quote: estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix, ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%

evidence.description: ANGSD nuclear contamination estimates for males: 0.2% to 2%
evidence.verbatim_quote: The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%

evidence.description: PTK001 excluded due to ~18% contamination estimate
evidence.verbatim_quote: PTK001 yielded a contamination estimate of around 18% and therefore was excluded from all further analysis

evidence.description: Pathogen screening found HBV in YUN048 and VAR021; VAR021 also positive for Salmonella enterica
evidence.verbatim_quote: apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV), while individual VAR021 was also positive for Salmonella enterica

evidence.description: Cut-off of 400,000 SNPs used for hapROH and imputation; >550,000 SNPs filtered for IBD analyses
evidence.verbatim_quote: We used a cut-off of 400,000 SNPs for hapROH and imputation and filtered for >550,000 SNPs for identity-by-descent (IBD) analyses

evidence.description: Varna necropolis dated 4600-4300 BC with large quantities of gold indicating unprecedented social stratification
evidence.verbatim_quote: The discovery of the necropolis of Varna (4600–4300 bc) on the Black Sea coast led to a reassessment of social inequality in human prehistory, with large quantities of gold and other symbols of power and wealth suggesting unprecedented levels of social stratification

evidence.description: Copper Age tell settlements (4900-3800 BC) involved in proto-industrial exploitation of copper, gold and salt
evidence.verbatim_quote: The many tell settlements that emerged during the Copper Age (CA, 4900–3800 bc) in SEE, involved in the proto-industrial exploitation of copper, gold and salt

evidence.description: Tell settlements and cemeteries abandoned roughly simultaneously around 4250/4200 BC
evidence.verbatim_quote: the roughly simultaneous abandonment of the numerous tell settlements and cemeteries around 4250/4200 bc appears enigmatic

evidence.description: Cucuteni-Trypillia megasites emerged around 4100-3800 BC with thousands of houses
evidence.verbatim_quote: huge settlements, with thousands of houses, the so-called megasites of the Cucuteni–Trypillia complex (around 4100–3800 bc), emerged

evidence.description: Yunatsite not resettled until about 1,000 years later during Early Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: Yunatsite not being resettled until about 1,000 years later during the Early Bronze Age (EBA)

claims.description: Early contact and admixture between CA farming groups from SEE and Eneolithic groups from the steppe zone occurred approximately 1,000 years earlier than previously anticipated
claims.verbatim_quote: from around 4500 bc on, groups from the northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries derived from Copper Age groups and those from the forest/steppe zones, indicating genetic and cultural contact over a period of around 1,000 years earlier than anticipated

claims.description: Transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders during early contact was integral to formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 BC
claims.verbatim_quote: We propose that the transfer of critical innovations between farmers and transitional foragers/herders from different ecogeographic zones during this early contact was integral to the formation, rise and expansion of pastoralist groups around 3300 bc

claims.description: Genetic continuity exists between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region of SEE
claims.verbatim_quote: While we observe genetic continuity between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in the same region

claims.description: SEE CA groups are genetically homogeneous with local continuity from preceding Neolithic populations
claims.verbatim_quote: outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region... suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale

claims.description: PIE060 likely came from a community outside Pietrele with recent contact with hunter-gatherers
claims.verbatim_quote: A flat decay curve supports the interpretation of a recent admixture date, which suggests that PIE060 came from a community outside Pietrele with recent contact with HGs

claims.description: Y-chromosomal diversity during SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe
claims.verbatim_quote: the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe

claims.description: SEE CA sites show wide-spread cultural, rather than close genetic, connectedness consistent with Gumelniţa-Kodžadermen-Karanovo VI complex
claims.verbatim_quote: These findings reflect the settlement density and the wide-spread cultural, rather than close genetic, connectedness of the Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex

claims.description: Ukraine Eneolithic cline reflects admixture between CA farmer-related groups and Eneolithic steppe groups over ~1,000 years
claims.verbatim_quote: This indicates possible admixture between CA farmer-related groups and Eneolithic steppe groups, as in line with cultural interactions described in the archaeological record. The observed genetic cline reflects developments over a wide chronological range of around 1,000 years

claims.description: Freshwater reservoir effect may affect some Ukraine Eneolithic 14C dates by up to ~500 years but individuals would still predate Yamnaya expansion
claims.verbatim_quote: an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc and thus considerably earlier than the Yamnaya-associated steppe pastoralist expansion

claims.description: Northwestern Black Sea region represents an interaction zone between late CA farming and steppe groups
claims.verbatim_quote: The archaeological record identifies the northwestern Black Sea region as an interaction zone between late CA farming and groups from the steppe region

claims.description: Previously reported 'Yamnaya-related ancestry' in Cucuteni-Trypillia individuals can be explained solely by increase in EHG-rich ancestry
claims.verbatim_quote: on re-analysis of these data we find that this signal can be explained solely by an increase in especially EHG-rich ancestry

claims.description: MAJ and USV have distinct admixture history from KTL individuals involving local SEE CA, Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and HG sources
claims.verbatim_quote: This provides strong support for an alternative admixture history for USV and MAJ, involving local SEE CA, Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and a HG-related source, a combination that is distinct from KTL individuals

claims.description: Smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups compared to preceding CA populations
claims.verbatim_quote: ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV, suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

claims.description: Absence of R1b-Z2103 or R1b-M269 precursor lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic indicates steppe-related ancestry expansion came later
claims.verbatim_quote: we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

claims.description: EBA YUN/PIE individuals show resurgence of HG ancestry without steppe-like ancestry, indicating presence of remnant HG groups
claims.verbatim_quote: EBA individuals from the fourth and third millennia bc from YUN and PIE do not show traces of steppe-like ancestry but instead a resurgence of HG ancestry observed widely in Europe during the fourth millennium bc

claims.description: All Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar
claims.verbatim_quote: all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

claims.description: Similar three-source admixture processes led to tripartite ancestry formation in steppe zone during fourth millennium BC for both Ukraine Eneolithic and Yamnaya
claims.verbatim_quote: We note that the same three sources contributed to the preceding Ukraine Eneolithic individuals from USV and MAJ (in addition to SEE CA ancestry), which suggests that similar processes had led to the tripartite ancestry formation in the steppe zone during the fourth millennium bc

claims.description: USV may have directly contributed to steppe pastoralists in third millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: which suggests a possible direct contribution of Ukraine Eneolithic groups to steppe pastoralists in the third millennium bc

claims.description: Subtle geographical structure exists in Yamnaya involving local genetic strata and influences from neighbouring groups in western and southern contact zones
claims.verbatim_quote: Despite the overlap in PCA, these results suggest subtle geographical structure, involving local genetic strata and influences from neighbouring groups in western and southern contact zones, respectively

claims.description: Genetic homogeneity of SEE CA matches cultural homogeneity of archaeological records suggesting extended period of stable sociopolitical network
claims.verbatim_quote: The genetic homogeneity observed in and across the four CA sites (PIE, YUN, PTK and VAR) of the fifth millennium bc matches the cultural homogeneity of the archaeological records and suggests an extended period of a relative stable sociopolitical network and absence of large-scale cultural and genetic transformations

claims.description: Genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts between genetically similar CA groups
claims.verbatim_quote: given the near-identical genetic ancestry profiles of SEE CA groups, we caution that genetic analyses would be blind to internal conflicts, causing the replacement of one CA group by another

claims.description: Early CA Gumelniţa groups had settled into steppe zone by mid-fifth millennium BC introducing farming lifestyle but also carrying HG cultural influences
claims.verbatim_quote: Archaeological evidence shows that the early CA Gumelniţa groups had already settled deep into the steppe zone by the mid-fifth millennium bc, introducing elements of a farming lifestyle but also carrying cultural influences from local HG groups

claims.description: Kartal site heterogeneity represents the transformative nature and dynamics of fourth millennium BC in action
claims.verbatim_quote: the heterogeneity of the individuals from the site Kartal stands out, which is located on the Danube delta at the northern end of the former distribution of the Chalcolithic Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex and thus represents the transformative nature and dynamics of the fourth millennium bc in action

claims.description: Contact and exchange between transitional foragers/early pastoralists and non-local SEE farmer groups started in late fifth millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: the more homogenous Majaky and Usatove groups, located north of the Dniester River, show that such assimilation processes had already occurred, suggesting that contact and exchange between transitional foragers and early pastoralist groups from the forest–steppe zone and non-local SEE farmer-associated groups had started already in the late fifth millennium bc

claims.description: Livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through interaction zones leading to fully developed pastoralism by end of fourth millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: We argue that livestock, innovations and technological advances were exchanged through these zones of interaction, which then led to the establishment of fully developed pastoralism in the steppe by the end of the fourth millennium bc

claims.description: Gene flow from both contact zones into steppe explains small amounts of farmer-related ancestry in emerging Yamnaya pastoralists
claims.verbatim_quote: Gene flow from both contact zones into the steppe could also explain the small amounts of farmer-related ancestry in the emerging Yamnaya pastoralists, which differentiates them from the Steppe Eneolithic substrate

claims.description: Early Eneolithic admixture was local to northwestern Black Sea region and did not affect SEE hinterland
claims.verbatim_quote: The early admixture during the Eneolithic presented in this study appears to be local to the northwestern Black Sea region of the fourth millennium bc and did not affect the hinterland in SEE

claims.description: Fourth millennium BC Europe showed mosaic of ancestries rather than genetically uniform populations
claims.verbatim_quote: This indicates the presence of remnant HG groups in various non-farmed regions, for example, highlands and uplands or densely forested zones and wetlands and a mosaic of ancestries rather than a genetically uniform CA and EBA Europe

claims.description: Interaction between local and incoming steppe groups in SEE did not result in near-complete genetic turnover as observed in Britain or Y-chromosome replacement as in Iberia
claims.verbatim_quote: The interaction between local and incoming groups in SEE did not result in archaeologically visible conflicts or a near-complete autosomal genetic turnover as observed in Britain or a replacement of the Y-chromosome lineages in the Iberian Peninsula

claims.description: BOY019 suggests interaction between neighbouring Usatove and Steppe Eneolithic groups OR direct descent from admixed groups like KTL001
claims.verbatim_quote: suggesting interaction between these two neighbouring groups in the western contact zone or alternatively direct descent from admixed groups (for example, KTL001)

claims.description: YUN041 and BOY019 bear witness to occasional admixture between EBA tell inhabitants and incoming steppe pastoralists
claims.verbatim_quote: Two outlier individuals from EBA YUN and BOY bear witness to occasional admixture between inhabitants of EBA tells and incoming steppe pastoralists

claims.description: Third millennium BC 'steppe ancestry' expected to have reached Great Hungarian plain from where it diversified and spread further west
claims.verbatim_quote: Ultimately, the third millennium bc form of 'steppe'-ancestry is expected to have reached the Great Hungarian plain, from where it diversified and spread further west

claims.description: The demise of CA settlements around 4250 BC may have involved depletion of resources, soil deterioration, violent conflicts, droughts, fires, or infectious diseases
claims.verbatim_quote: The underlying circumstances are unclear and might have involved the depletion of resources, the deterioration of soils and possibly also violent conflicts... Long-lasting droughts and forest fires or infectious diseases and ensuing epidemics are other factors that could deplete lands

claims.description: Variable cultural influences attested by archaeological record are also traceable genetically
claims.verbatim_quote: variable cultural influences attested by the archaeological record are also traceable genetically

claims.description: High-quality genome-wide data from fifth and fourth millennia BC allowing IBD tracing will be key to understanding West Eurasian population history
claims.verbatim_quote: High-quality genome-wide data from the fifth and fourth millennia bc that allow the direct tracing of IBD blocks shared by contributing groups will hold the key to understanding the population history of West Eurasia

claims.description: Relatively large effective population sizes during SEE CA consistent with previous observations across early farming societies
claims.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes, consistent with previous observation across early farming societies

claims.description: Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures were heavily influenced by local CA cultures and surroundings
claims.verbatim_quote: The succeeding Cernavodă I and Usatove archaeological cultures were heavily influenced by local CA cultures and surrounds

claims.description: Northwestern Pontic region experienced intensified contact with Steppe Eneolithic groups during fourth millennium BC while they also had contact with North Caucasus groups like Maykop
claims.verbatim_quote: During the fourth millennium bc, the northwestern Pontic region experienced intensified contact with Steppe Eneolithic groups, while these in turn also had contact with groups in the North Caucasus, such as Maykop, all of which are mirrored by the genomic data presented here

claims.description: Shared shorter IBD tracts between sites are consistent with transregional connectivity visible in material culture
claims.verbatim_quote: Shared shorter IBD tracts between sites are consistent with the transregional connectivity visible in the material culture

claims.description: No pathogen evidence found among CA individuals of fifth and fourth millennium BC except for HBV in two individuals
claims.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV)

claims.description: EBA tell resettlement involved groups with burial rites not associated with incoming steppe groups
claims.verbatim_quote: the resettlement of sites like Tell Yunatsite involved groups with burial rites not associated with the incoming steppe groups

claims.description: Steppe pastoralists associated with Yamnaya cultural complex can be traced genetically at Majaky and Boyanovo in third millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: we can trace the appearance of migrants from the steppe, clearly attributed to Yamnaya culturally and genetically, in the local time transect at Majaky but also at Boyanovo in the Bulgarian lowlands of the Thracian Plain

claims.description: Gumelniţa-Kodžadermen-Karanovo VI complex from around 4600 BC indicates transregional connectedness and relatively stable sociopolitical network
claims.verbatim_quote: From around 4600 bc, the similarity and continuous development of material culture and exchange of raw materials in the so-called Gumelniţa–Kodžadermen–Karanovo VI complex across southern Romania (Gumelniţa), northern Bulgaria (Kodžadermen) and Thrace (Karanovo) indicate transregional connectedness and suggest a relatively stable sociopolitical network

claims.description: Single-source qpAdm modelling confirms shared local ancestry for PIE039 (P = 0.41)
claims.verbatim_quote: could be used as a single source for proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41), confirming shared local ancestry

claims.description: Scenarios involving gene flow from Caucasus would require additional WHG/EHG-like ancestry source not sufficiently represented by SEE CA or Caucasus Maykop
claims.verbatim_quote: This affinity towards WHG/EHG is absent when Steppe Eneolithic is used, implying that scenarios involving potential gene flow from the Caucasus would require an additional source carrying WHG-/EHG-like ancestry as this ancestry is not sufficiently represented by SEE CA or Caucasus Maykop groups

claims.description: Cernavodă I culture at Kartal shows genetic heterogeneity reflecting boundary zone dynamics
claims.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous

claims.description: Two main genetic turnover events in prehistoric western Eurasia: farming spread (7000-6000 BC) and pastoralist expansion (from 3300 BC)
claims.verbatim_quote: Archaeogenetic studies have described two main genetic turnover events in prehistoric western Eurasia: one associated with the spread of farming and a sedentary lifestyle starting around 7000–6000 bc and a second with the expansion of pastoralist groups from the Eurasian steppes starting around 3300 bc

claims.description: Maykop culture critical in development of metal alloys, early horse domestication and sheep-wool economy with extensive dairy production
claims.verbatim_quote: the North Caucasian Maykop culture was critical in the further development of metal alloys, as well as early horse domestication and a sheep-wool economy combined with extensive dairy production

claims.description: Higher background relatedness at intrasite level at Yunatsite and Varna compared to Pietrele explained by site structure differences
claims.verbatim_quote: we find higher background relatedness at the intrasite level at Yunatsite and Varna compared to Pietrele, which can be explained by the structure of the sites (a destruction horizon of households and a burial ground with shorter use, respectively, versus tell and settlement burials spanning 350–400 years)

claims.description: IBD similarities between MAJ and USV reflect close geographical vicinity and chronological overlap
claims.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites

claims.description: Despite close geographical proximity of Ukrainian sites, different admixture histories could be traced
claims.verbatim_quote: despite the close geographical proximity of the Ukrainian sites studied, we were able to trace different admixture histories

claims.description: Northwestern Black Sea region played central role in development of oldest wheeled vehicles
claims.verbatim_quote: The North Pontic region played a central role in the development of the oldest wheeled vehicles

claims.description: Period between farming spread and pastoralist expansion saw key innovations including metallurgy, wheel and wagon, and horse domestication
claims.verbatim_quote: The period between these events saw new economies emerging on the basis of key innovations, including metallurgy, wheel and wagon and horse domestication

claims.description: Gimbutas's proposal of early 'Indo-European' expansion from steppe causing CA collapse possible but internal CA competition equally likely
claims.verbatim_quote: Conflict arising from an early expansion of supposedly 'Indo-European' groups from the steppe, an idea that was put forward by M. Gimbutas, is possible but internal competition and strife between CA groups is equally likely

claims.description: Yamnaya Caucasus confirms findings of Lazaridis et al. regarding Steppe Eneolithic and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop mixture
claims.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, confirming the findings of Lazaridis and colleagues

claims.description: Ozera outlier consistent with influence from the Caucasus based on PCA position and qpAdm model
claims.verbatim_quote: consistent with the position in PCA and corroborating an influence from the Caucasus

claims.description: Subtle differences in genetic ancestries between MAJ_EBA, BOY_EBA and other Yamnaya groups account for geographical locations and stages of cultural assimilation
claims.verbatim_quote: The subtle differences in genetic ancestries between these two when compared to different Yamnaya-associated groups account for their geographical locations and different stages of genetic and perhaps, cultural assimilation

claims.description: Settlement activity was scarce in western Black Sea region after CA collapse indicating a 'dark' millennium
claims.verbatim_quote: settlement activity over the following centuries was scarce in the entire western Black Sea region, indicating a 'dark' millennium

claims.description: Burial mounds associated with Yamnaya extended along Danube valley into Carpathian Basin during third millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: Burial mounds, associated with the Yamnaya cultural complex, appear frequently and extend along the Danube valley into the Carpathian Basin during the third millennium bc

claims.description: Gradual transition from foraging to semi-nomadic pastoralism followed in North Pontic region during sixth and fourth millennium BC
claims.verbatim_quote: From the contact zones in the northwestern Black Sea region and the Caucasus, a gradual transition from foraging to semi-nomadic pastoralism also followed in the North Pontic region during the sixth and fourth millennium bc

claims.description: All 14C dates in the study are consistent with archaeological chronology based on stratigraphy and grave goods
claims.verbatim_quote: All 14C dates in this study are consistent with the archaeological chronology based on stratigraphy and grave goods

claims.description: Re-analysis of Immel et al. data shows reported Yamnaya-related ancestry in Cucuteni-Trypillia can be explained by EHG-rich ancestry alone
claims.verbatim_quote: Such an early interaction has been postulated by Immel et al., who have reported Yamnaya-related ancestry in individuals associated with the Cucuteni–Trypillia complex from today's Moldova. However, on re-analysis of these data we find that this signal can be explained solely by an increase in especially EHG-rich ancestry

claims.description: Replication is not applicable as study analyses unique entities of past populations
claims.verbatim_quote: We study unique entities of past populations and did not use different treatments or variations of data analyses, so replication is not applicable

implicit_arguments.description: Ancient DNA from well-preserved petrous bones and teeth can reliably reconstruct population history spanning 3,000 years
PCA projection of ancient individuals onto modern genetic variation provides meaningful spatial representation of genetic affinities
qpAdm ancestry modelling can distinguish between different admixture scenarios and source populations despite temporal and geographic separation
Archaeological cultural designations (Cernavodă I, Usatove, Yamnaya) correspond to meaningful genetic groupings
Genetic admixture indicates sustained social contact and interaction between populations rather than isolated events
Y-chromosome and mitochondrial lineage patterns can be used as proxies for sex-biased migration and admixture processes
Runs of homozygosity (ROH) patterns provide reliable estimates of effective population size and mating patterns in ancient populations
Identity-by-descent (IBD) sharing between ancient individuals indicates biological kinship or shared recent ancestry at the population level
Technological innovations (metallurgy, wheel, animal domestication) could spread through genetic admixture or cultural transmission along contact zones
The formation of pastoralist societies required both genetic input and knowledge transfer from multiple source populations across different ecological zones

research_designs.name: Multi-site comparative archaeogenomic study
research_designs.description: Genome-wide ancient DNA analysis of 135 individuals from eight archaeological sites spanning approximately 3,000 years (5400-2400 BC) across southeastern Europe and northwestern Black Sea region to trace genetic continuity, admixture, and population dynamics between farming and pastoralist societies

research_designs.name: Temporal transect design
research_designs.description: Chronological sampling strategy covering Neolithic (n=1), Copper Age (n=95), Eneolithic (n=18), and Early Bronze Age (n=21) to track genetic changes through time periods and correlate with archaeological cultural phases

research_designs.name: Genetic ancestry modelling framework
research_designs.description: Systematic application of distal and proximal qpAdm ancestry modelling with cornerstone populations (Turkey_N, WHG, EHG, CHG) to quantify ancestry contributions and test alternative admixture scenarios

research_designs.name: Multi-proxy genetic analysis
research_designs.description: Integration of autosomal DNA, Y-chromosome haplogroups, mitochondrial DNA, and multiple analytical approaches (PCA, f-statistics, qpAdm, IBD, ROH) to provide convergent evidence for population history reconstruction

methods.name: 1,240,000 SNP capture enrichment
methods.description: Targeted in-solution capture for approximately 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms using established ancient DNA protocols
methods.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel)

methods.name: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
methods.description: PCA constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 populations using smartpca v.16000 with ancient individuals projected using lsqproject and shrinkmode options
methods.verbatim_quote: principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

methods.name: qpAdm ancestry modelling
methods.description: Quantitative ancestry proportion estimation using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS v.5.1 with distal and proximal source populations and rotating outgroup approaches
methods.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling and ancestry proportion estimation on the 1,240,000 SNP dataset was performed using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS (v.5.1)

methods.name: f4-statistics and f3-statistics
methods.description: Outgroup f3 statistics calculated using qp3Pop for genetic relatedness; f4 statistics calculated using qpDstat with f4mode:YES for testing excess shared ancestry with cornerstone populations
methods.verbatim_quote: Outgroup f3 statistics were calculated using qp3Pop to obtain the genetic relatedness of a target population to a set of ancient Eurasian populations

methods.name: Identity-by-descent (IBD) analysis
methods.description: IBD sharing analysis using ancIBD v.0.4 on imputed data with >600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities >0.99, filtering for blocks >5cM with >220 SNPs/cM
methods.verbatim_quote: IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE

methods.name: Runs of homozygosity (ROH) analysis
methods.description: ROH estimation using hapROH v.0.64 on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data with >400,000 SNP threshold to assess parental relatedness and effective population size
methods.verbatim_quote: The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data

methods.name: READ genetic relatedness estimation
methods.description: Genetic relatedness estimation using READ software with default parameters, using median value across sites per temporal group for background relatedness
methods.verbatim_quote: Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings

methods.name: DATES admixture timing estimation
methods.description: Software DATES v.753 used to estimate admixture timing by measuring decay of ancestry covariance, assuming single admixture event and 28-year generation time
methods.verbatim_quote: The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years

methods.name: GLIMPSE imputation
methods.description: Genotype imputation using GLIMPSE v.1.0.1 with 1000G reference panel, 2Mb chunks with 200kb buffer, retaining samples with >0.5× coverage on 1,240,000 positions
methods.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters

methods.name: Y-chromosome haplogroup assignment
methods.description: Manual assignment method for Y-haplogroup calling with YMCA capture assay targeting ~10,445 kB on non-recombining Y chromosome region
methods.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling

methods.name: Mitochondrial haplogroup assignment
methods.description: mtDNA consensus sequences aligned to revised Cambridge Reference Sequence (NC 012920.1), haplogroups assigned using HaploGrep2 v.2.4.0
methods.verbatim_quote: HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup

methods.name: Radiocarbon dating
methods.description: AMS 14C dating at Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH, calibrated using IntCal20 database and OxCal v.4.4.2
methods.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany

methods.name: Metagenomic pathogen screening
methods.description: Shotgun data screened using HOPS v.0.2 pipeline with MALT v.0.4.0 mapping to custom RefSeq database including bacterial, viral genomes and human reference GRCh38
methods.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2)

methods.name: Contamination estimation
methods.description: mtDNA contamination estimated using ContamMix; nuclear contamination for males estimated using ANGSD
methods.verbatim_quote: estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix... The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD

methods.name: Sex determination
methods.description: Genetic sex estimated by calculating coverage on X, Y, and autosomal chromosomes with X and Y coverage normalised by autosomal coverage and relative chromosome length
methods.verbatim_quote: We estimated the genetic sex by calculating the coverage on the X, Y and the autosomal chromosomes

methods.name: Spearman correlation test
methods.description: Non-parametric correlation testing between PC2 positions and 14C dates for Ukraine Eneolithic individuals
methods.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

protocols.name: Minimally-invasive petrous bone sampling
protocols.description: Petrous bones sampled using minimal invasive method following protocols.io protocol bqd8ms9w
protocols.verbatim_quote: Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method

protocols.name: Tooth sampling protocol
protocols.description: Crown separated from root and inner pulp chamber drilled out following protocols.io protocol bqebmtan
protocols.verbatim_quote: for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out

protocols.name: Ancient DNA extraction
protocols.description: DNA extracted using modified Dabney et al. protocol following protocols.io protocol baksicwe
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol

protocols.name: Half-UDG library preparation
protocols.description: Double-stranded DNA libraries built with partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment following protocols.io protocol bmh6k39e
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment

protocols.name: Single-stranded library preparation
protocols.description: Automated protocol for single-stranded, non-UDG libraries for samples not meeting initial threshold
protocols.verbatim_quote: For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries

protocols.name: Double-indexing protocol
protocols.description: Libraries double-indexed with unique index pairs following protocols.io protocol bvt8n6rw
protocols.verbatim_quote: All libraries were double-indexed with a unique pair of indices

protocols.name: Shotgun screening protocol
protocols.description: Initial screening via shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on HiSeq4000 or NextSeq500 (1×75bp) for quality assessment
protocols.verbatim_quote: all indexed libraries were screened by means of shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on an Illumina HiSeq4000 or NextSeq500 sequencing platform using a single end (1 × 75 base pair (bp) reads) kit

protocols.name: 1,240,000 SNP capture protocol
protocols.description: Libraries above 0.1% endogenous DNA threshold enriched for ~1.2 million SNPs via targeted in-solution capture
protocols.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture

protocols.name: Sequencing depth protocol
protocols.description: Enriched libraries sequenced on HiSeq4000/NextSeq500 with 40M reads for 0.1-2% endogenous or 20M reads for >2% endogenous samples
protocols.verbatim_quote: sequencing 40 million reads for libraries between 0.1% and 2% or 20 million reads for libraries above 2%

protocols.name: Mitochondrial capture protocol
protocols.description: Additional mitochondrial capture for individuals with insufficient mtDNA reads from 1,240,000 capture by-catch
protocols.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture

protocols.name: YMCA Y-chromosome capture
protocols.description: In-house capture assay for Y chromosome targeting ~10,445 kB on non-recombining region for selected males
protocols.verbatim_quote: For selected male individuals we also performed an inhouse capture assay for the Y chromosome (YMCA) which targets around 10.445 kB on the non-combining region of the Y chromosome

protocols.name: EAGER pipeline processing
protocols.description: Raw sequence processing using EAGER v.1.92.56 including adapter trimming (AdapterRemoval v.2.3.0), mapping to hs37d5 (BWA v.0.7.12), duplicate removal (DeDup v.0.12.1)
protocols.verbatim_quote: EAGER v.1.92.56 was used to process raw ancient DNA sequence data

protocols.name: DNA damage assessment
protocols.description: mapDamage v.2.0.9 used to analyse characteristic G→A and C→T substitution patterns
protocols.verbatim_quote: To analyse characteristic DNA damage in the form of G to A and C to T substitutions, mapDamage v.2.0.9 was used

protocols.name: Damage trimming protocol
protocols.description: 2bp trimmed from 3′ and 5′ ends of UDG-half treated reads; 10bp trimmed from non-UDG single-stranded libraries for quality controls
protocols.verbatim_quote: The effect of postmortem DNA damage on genotyping was minimized by removing 2 bp from the 3′ and 5′ ends of reads from double-stranded UDG-half-treated libraries

protocols.name: Pseudohaploid genotyping
protocols.description: pileupCaller v.1.4.0.2 used for genotyping with randomHaploid option, singleStrandMode for non-UDG libraries
protocols.verbatim_quote: The resulting filtered bam files were genotyped with pileupCaller v.1.4.0.2 by randomly calling one allele per position considering the human genome as a pseudohaploid genome

protocols.name: Data quality filtering
protocols.description: Samples filtered by SNP coverage: >30,000 SNPs for PCA; >400,000 SNPs for hapROH/imputation; >550,000 SNPs for IBD; >600,000 SNPs with GP>0.99 for ancIBD
protocols.verbatim_quote: We used a cut-off of 400,000 SNPs for hapROH and imputation and filtered for >550,000 SNPs for identity-by-descent (IBD) analyses

protocols.name: Relatedness handling protocol
protocols.description: First-degree relatives: lower-SNP individual excluded; identical individuals merged; same-individual samples from different publications merged
protocols.verbatim_quote: From pairs of first-degree relatives, the individual with lower number of SNPs on the 1,240,000 target region was excluded from downstream analysis

protocols.name: Contamination exclusion threshold
protocols.description: Samples with ~18% or higher contamination estimates excluded from analysis (e.g., PTK001)
protocols.verbatim_quote: PTK001 yielded a contamination estimate of around 18% and therefore was excluded from all further analysis

protocols.name: qpAdm outgroup selection
protocols.description: Basic outgroup set for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG; adjusted per test
protocols.verbatim_quote: The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG

protocols.name: DATES parameter settings
protocols.description: DATES run with binsize 0.001, maxdis 1, qbin 10, lovalfit 0.45; reference populations chosen based on best-fitting qpAdm model
protocols.verbatim_quote: The following parameters were used for every run: binsize 0.001; maxdis 1; qbin 10; lovalfit 0.45

protocols.name: IBD quality filtering
protocols.description: Only shared blocks >220 SNPs/cM and >5cM retained for analysis and plotting
protocols.verbatim_quote: only shared blocks of more than 220 SNPs per centimorgan and shared blocks of more than 5 cM were kept for data quality purposes

protocols.name: Reference dataset merging
protocols.description: New data merged with Allen Ancient DNA Resource (AADR) v.44.3 on Human Origins (~600K SNPs) and 1,240,000 panels
protocols.verbatim_quote: For genome-wide analyses the new data from this study were merged with published ancient and modern data from the Allen Ancient DNA Resource (AADR) v.44.3

protocols.name: Transition filtering for Y-chromosome
protocols.description: For non-UDG treated sequences, YMCA data filtered to exclude C→T and G→A transitions on forward and reverse strands respectively
protocols.verbatim_quote: In the case of non-UDG treated sequence, YMCA data were filtered to exclude C to T and G to A transitions on the forward and reverse strands, respectively

protocols.name: HOPS pathogen authentication
protocols.description: Pathogen candidates authenticated based on edit distance distribution, ancient DNA damage pattern, and read distribution along reference genome
protocols.verbatim_quote: The results were filtered with a predefined list of pathogens of interest and possible candidates authenticated on the basis of edit distance distribution, ancient DNA damage pattern and read distribution along the reference genome

funding.acknowledgement_text: We thank E. Kukral, F. Aron, L. Semerau, A. Wissgott, G. Brandt, S. Nagel and E. Essel for their support in the ancient DNA analyses and S. Clayton and K. Prüfer for the processing of the raw sequence data. We thank the teams at (former) MPI-SHH-Archaeogenetics and MPI-EVA-Archaeogenetics for continued support and discussion. This research was funded by the Max Planck Society, the European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement nos 771234-PALEoRIDER, W.H.; 834616-ARCHCAUCASUS, S.H.; and 678901-FoodTransforms, P.W.S.) and the ERA.Net RUS Plus initiative (S&T-277-BIOARCCAUCASUS, S.H.).

machine_actionability.rationale: Data deposited in standardised repository (ENA) with accession number allowing programmatic retrieval

code_availability.access_conditions: No dedicated code repository; analysis uses established software packages (EAGER, ANGSD, qpAdm, ancIBD, hapROH, GLIMPSE, DATES)

machine_actionability.rationale: Standard bioinformatics tools are well-documented but no custom analysis scripts provided

contributions: W.H., S.H., P.W.S. and J.K. designed the study
R.K., G.G.-R., C.S., M.A.S., G.U.N., A. Chohadzhiev, A.S., K.P., S.R., M.L., I.M., B.G., K. Boyadzhiev, Y.B., K. Beutler and I.B. provided materials and resources
S.P., A.B.R., G.G.-R., C.S., G.U.N. and A. Childebayeva analysed the data
W.H., I.M., S.H., P.W.S., Y.B. and K. Boyadzhiev assisted with data interpretation
S.P., S.H., P.W.S., I.M., A.B.R. and W.H. wrote the manuscript with contributions from all co-authors

declarations: The authors declare no competing interests

details: Ancient DNA study from archaeological remains - no ethics approval statement provided or typically required for archaeological skeletal material

fieldwork_permits: Sampling conducted with permission from museums and archaeological institutions in Bulgaria, Romania, Moldova and Ukraine

items.description: Sample metadata including radiocarbon dates, SNP counts
Individual sample details with PCA coordinates
Archaeological context, statistical results, and genetic analyses

extraction_notes.section_extracted: Pass 0-7 complete - Full extraction pipeline finished
known_uncertainties: Some statistical p-values and model fits may vary slightly depending on parameter settings
Freshwater reservoir effect may affect some radiocarbon dates by up to 500 years
DATES admixture timing estimates assume single pulse admixture model
